moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. h3 b6 3. Bf4 g6 4. Nf3 d6 5: White needed to go play Bf1, Bc2, or Bb1.  This loses the exchange.
moves.17... Nxe3: I am content to exchange Queens, after all, I am currently a Rook ahead.
moves.18. Bxd8 Nxd1 19. Be7: This and White's next are his saving grace.
moves.20... Nxf2: The Knight was doomed.  This seemed better to me than anything else; at least I have the exchange and a pawn.
moves.21. Kxf2 f6 22. Bd6 b5 23. a4 Bf8: The Bishop exchange is not quite forced.  Bc7 is available but after Rac1 White must either trade or removed the Bishop from action for the moment.
moves.24. Bxf8 Rexf8 25. Kg1 h6 26. b3 Bc6: I like my pawn structure at the moment.
Making way for the Rook at a8.
moves.32. Nb1 Ra8 33. Bc2 Ra2 34. exf6+ Kxf6 3: Taking the pawn while improving my position.
moves.43. Kd2 Na4: I now believe Ba4 would have been better.
moves.44. Kc1 c3 45. Ne5 Nb6 46. Ne5d3 Ra2: Perhaps I should have looked at exchanging some material first.
moves.50. Nxc2 Na4 51. Kc1 e5 52. Nab4: If instead 52. Kd1 then 52. --- Nb2+ wins the a2 Knight.
moves.52... Nb6 53. dxe5+ Ke6: 53. --- Kxe5 allows the Knight fork at c6.
moves.54. Kd1 Rf7: Removing the fork and threatening the pawn at e5.
moves.56... Nxe5: Taking the pawn while it is available and threatening to swap Knights.
moves.57. Kc2: Additional protection for the Knight and attacking Black's c pawn.
Taking the pawn in the mistaken belief that the c1 square is still guarded.
